instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I've got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which is only showing 1v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and about 300 ohms to ground.

There was corrosion around <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1617</RESISTOR> which I've cleaned up and repaired during my first pass over the board, but apart from that it's clean with no other visible issues.

Pulled F7140 and showing 12.7v on pin 1 with a 155ohm, and 500ohm on pin 2.

Any suggestions on the best way forward?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check if any big coil has the same value to ground.
L7520/60 for example...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L7520 has 420 to ground on both legs
L7560 is 150 on both legs...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L7430 is 125 on both legs
L3095 is 500 on both legs
L7320 & L7310 are 50 on both legs

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post EXACT ohm value to ground on both pins of <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR>; red probe to ground.
Also check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> value to ground removing <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.
Be AWARE, do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>!!!
Also check removing F7700 and <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>.

BTW, post first diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with black probe to ground.
Maybe you do NOT have any issue there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]Post EXACT ohm value to ground on both pins of <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR>; red probe to ground..[/QUOTE]

Pin 1 - 484ohm
Pin 2 - 475ohm

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]Also check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> value to ground removing <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.
Be AWARE, do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>!!![/QUOTE]

I'll come back to you on this.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]Also check removing F7700 and <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>.[/QUOTE]

I'll come back to you on this.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]BTW, post first diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with black probe to ground.
Maybe you do NOT have any issue there..[/QUOTE]

With black to ground this is open (checked on pin 2 of F7140)...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"Pin 2 - 475ohm
With black to ground this is open (checked on pin 2 of F7140)"
Then looks like good values.
If <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> disappears when solder F7040, you should have problem with some secondary supply.
Probably 3/5V, change <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Back down to 1.6v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I'll swap <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Swapped <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and it looks like we're still the same.

threads.message: Post exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.message:
"27 & 28: 718 ohms"
Check schematic and fix that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, but that resistance remains. Damage in the board, or have I missed something?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Don't you think to check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22???
And traces, of course...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, all tested OK, but it looks like my replacement <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> might have been dead, I've swapped it again and we have fan spin. Need to test fully, but looks like it's OK. Thanks for your help!
